reviewText:
Fox & Flock is a neat little board game. Something you play for a half hour to kill some time. Sadly, it's very light on features, almost feeling like a demo for a full featured game. But for under $2.00 I *really* can't complain. Overall, I really enjoyed it and I hope the creators decide to make a chess game with the same aesthetics.

The Good:
++Fun game!
++Fantastic art style
++Fitting classical soundtrack
+Narrator is quite entertaining
+Local Multiplayer
+Steam Cards

The Bad:
-No online play
-Story mode is short (about 20 minutes; I guess you can think of it as a tutorial)
-Lack of game modes

The Ugly (which hopefully get patched) :
---Questionable AI (Dumb moves, or the AI just repeats the same two moves over and over, really dragging down the flow of the game)
---Game breaking glitches, requiring game restart
---Inability to use Steam overlay or take screenshots
voteText: 18 of 18 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The game rules are fairly simply.  I am not going to try to explain them in detail here, it would be a waste of your time but if you are a fan of games like GO, Chess and Checkers you will be on familiar ground.  If you are not a checkers pro, fear not; there is a quick tutorial game that teaches everything you need to know about the rules in about three moves.

Throughout the Story mode you play as both the Fox and the Flock.   Each round is tied together by voice acted narrative poetry.  Which is good, the voice acting and poetry, both.   The Story is to-the-point but interesting, not that it takes much to push an hour of gameplay.  The Music is excellent, as it is time-appropriate Classical that really sets the mood.  The orchestrated score contrasts nicely with the subtle blood stains that accumulate each time a fox eats (jumps) a member of the Flock.  The simple hand drawn art style also lends well to the overall Ball-Room Era theme of F&F.  It really looks like you are playing the game on the page of an old weathered book or something of the like.

The real challenge is to be had in the Quick-Game mode.  The Quick Game mode is the place to go if you are looking to crank up the difficulty or play a two player match, locally.  The Story Mode was quite short, to be sure.  None the less, I found Fox and Flock rather enjoyable... and the story mode even has a twist ending... which was more than what I was expecting.  Well worth the two Dollar Price tag.

reviewText:
I'm a huge fan of board games for my computer. Anything I can fire up quickly, learn how to master, and just keep for those days when my more heavy duty games aren't keeping my interest is always something I'm willing to add to my list.

I've never played the game that inspired Fox & Flock so I made sure I played close attention to the tutorial. This is a very quick game to learn and I have a special love for things that come from the 1800s so color me already interested.

The music is very relaxing and puts you in the ballroom mood while you'll be very entertained with the charming place markers of the flock and foxes. (Go foxes, uhm color me biased!)

There is a bit of a storyline during your adventures if you choose not to indulge in quick games and there is a lovely little narration with voice acting that I did enjoy. It was something that most people overlook in games like this so I enjoyed it. (Fur standing on end... Thank you for keeping in character the entire time, too. People really do overlook things like this.)

There's no flashy graphics to give you a migraine. There's no complicated keystrokes. This is a game you can unwind with and include within your big titles just to have to wind down with...of course until the AI figures out what your game is and you're left cursing at the screen. Nothing painful unless we count your self-inflicted pain when that turkey in a ballgown has blocked your path to the noms. Multiple times. Accept your fate, turkey. Just accept your fate.

I guess that would be my gripe. Much like tic-tac-toe, there's more of a let's go for deadlock" than a winning combination. There weren't too many risks the AI was willing to make in order to win
date: making it so difficult that I had to frequently restart...\n\nWhich leads to one HUGELY GLARING DETAIL. This game has a major bug. If dialogue fails to intiate between matches to tell you if you're foxes or flocks(es haha rhyme) or to announce who has won
recommended: you will freeze and you will not proceed. The game will not save what has happened. This has occurred a few times to me so far. Now it's not frustrating as I'm fine to replay the level. No harm
hoursPlayed: no foul! (Or should we say fowl? haha flock
voteText: haha animals
helpfulPercent: oh I'm way too tickled with this one!) But that is a little annoying so I hope that's fixed soon. This COULD deter people from downloading because if you spent a long time on a particularly difficult match
votesHelpful: you're not going to want to replay that again.\n\nBugs aside
votesTotal: this game really fulfills a lot of things that I do love and I find myself selfishly saying to download the game despite the buggyness and just play through it because it really is fun to waste an hour just moving those animal pegs around.\n\nAlso
votesFunny: a fox does deserve a good meal
commentsCount: after all. How dare they look down upon the foxes? You all taste good with ketchup and ale in the end!"

reviewText:
Fox and Flock is a lovely adaptation of a classic strategy board game that has been around for centuries.  This version plants the core game itself inside a dark tale rich with comedy and tragedy ~ uninvited Guests at a ball.

I greatly enjoyed the production value of the game; the artwork was quite well done and the choice of baroque period music fits very well with the story..  My only minor complaint was that the perspective of the board at times makes it difficult to see where pieces are or where they are not, and it would have been nice if the board had been rotated on a slight angle to prevent this.

All in all I Highly recommend this to strategy lovers and anyone else who might appreciate something a little more casual than your typical action-oriented game.

reviewText: Old board game with story tutorial.\n\nWhile you will probably enjoy playing this old game[en.wikipedia.org] more against an actual human on an actual board (or perhaps via Internet and the Tabletop Simulator), this game teaches anyone (and thanks to full voice-overs, that means children, too) the basics of this game. There's the tutorial"
date: and then there's a short campaign with poetic narration; it took me half an hour to complete.\n\nIf you have no one to play with
recommended: you can challenge the AI to a quick game. Its difficulty ranges from "dolt" to "aristocrat". I played a classic game as fox
hoursPlayed: and the aristocratic AI not only happily repeats the same moves forever (which should ordinarily be a stalemate)
voteText: it also did some fairly dumb mistakes in the endgame that gave a certain victory away. So there seems room for improvement.\n\nFox & Flock is a fun way to learn a classic game

reviewText:
Short version: 63%If you like halatafl (fox & geese), you’ll like Fox & Flock, since it is nothing more than a video game adaptation of the classic board game with a reasonable AI and no multiplayer.

Long version:Fox & Flock had a simple goal: create a video game version of the old medieval board game of halatafl, also known as fox & geese.
If you haven’t met it yet, halatafl is a fairly easy game, sort of a combination of checkers and GO, where the large amount of geese are trying to trap the foxes in a corner while the foxes try to eat them. It also has the same fundamental flaw, whereas it is easy to reach a stalemate.

This video game only added a short, roughly 30-minutes, somewhat dark and baroque story mode on it. It’s not much, but the AI seems decent to entertain you for a few minutes or so, since there is no multiplayer to play against humans.

reviewText:
It's difficult to criticize cheap games, but I found myself not pleased with my overall experience of the game. The length of the main part of the game is to be expected, so no problems there. However, there is so little replay value even with the quick game option. No multiplayer is a glaring example. My experience with the game in both story and quick play has been to repeat the same moves repeatedly until the ai eventually makes a mistake. If the aim of the game is to win, then I find this to be the best tactic. Of course, the potential exists to not play like this, but also increases the chances of losing on the hardest difficulty.

On the topic of replayability, there is also no reason to play the game again. No achievements, no collectibles, no unlockables. The only incentive currently is steam trading cards (the reason my playtime is higher than 1h). Perhaps this will change if the developer wishes to add content to the game in the future. It's quite easy to see features being implemented such as new visual elements, new music, new gameplay modes, multiplayer, character skins, challenges and so on. Maybe one day there will be new features or options.

The aesthetics of the game are certainly interesting, including the opera style theme music. Initially, the game is quite unique, but after ten minutes the specialness of playing something different was already gone, as I found myself repeating the same combination of movements. Is a unique aesthetic enough to justify purchasing a game that will potentially last between 20-60 minutes? Despite the price, I would say it is not. The game certainly isn't bad by any means, I just don't believe that what it currently offers justifies the (admittedly low) cost of the game.

P.S, I also dislike not being able to turn off music or sounds. After having the game on for 3 hours for steam trading cards (I have something of an ocd about booster pack eligibility), I now hate opera forever.

reviewText:
Lovely concept, but unfortunately not much content.
I have enjoyed this game each of the three times I played it through. I could listen to the narrator time and time again, but his beautiful words won't change the fact that there is not much to be played. I don't remember exactly how long it took me to play the story through the first time, maybe 25-40 minutes. Aside story mode you can play a quick game, where you get to choose difficulty, faction played etc, but I did not notice any more challenge in these games than in the story mode, and couldn't bother playing them for long.

Some pros:
- Lovely art style and character desings
- Narrator and the story he tells
- Very cheap, and often on sale

Some cons:
- When controlling multiple characters hard to distinguish which one is being controlled
- Story is really short
- Quick game doesn't really offer any more challenge

In the end, if you are looking for a little game that keeps you occupied up to an hour, 5/5, would recommend. Unfortunately that's all there is to this game.

reviewText: This game is short. And yet, a delectable morsel to behold.\n\nIntelligent Games really outdid themselves with this game. It's simple. It's clean. It's elegant in design, aesthetics, and wonderful in music. And yet they managed to accomplish this with such minimalistic assets. This game truly goes to show just how little material and how a lot of polish can really bring out a wonderful game. That and a brilliant voice actor who narrates the game and really does bring the charm of this little puzzle to life. It isn't innovative" per se
date: as the game is an adaption of a long lived game
recommended: but its style is something that is not commonly seen in video gaming: stuffy Victorian animals drawn on parchment with clean calligraphic ink strokes on dancing "Fox & Geese" board to the accompaniment of orchestral ballroom music.\n\nThe game is simple. There are two parties. The Fox and the Flock. The Fox wishes to eat the Flock. The Flock wishes to not be eaten. The Fox must cleverly snatch and kill the Flock
hoursPlayed: one by one. The Flock must either herd at the exit or corner the Fox before there are too few to resist the Fox. But the Fox is limited by wanting to remain unidentifiable by the Flock he's hunted
voteText: thus he can only attack one nearby Flock at a time provided there is room. And the Flock
votesHelpful: refuse to be caught "uncivilized" by dancing improperly
votesTotal: thus limiting their own movement to escape the Fox. You will alternate between the two parties
votesFunny:
either guiding the Fox to a fat dinner before his quarry escapes or aiding the Flock in their attempt to flee their foe.

It's all very elegantly done: clean and straightforward. No gimmicks. No flash. No distractions.

I do have one complaint about the game
commentsCount: and that it's sometimes difficult to get a fuller view of the board considering how the pieces do take up a lot of space with their art. It isn't a horrible complaint
column16: especially as the game gives you a simplified board view off to the side
column19: did frustrate me.\n\nBut for the meager price of 2$? I say it was more than worth it. You can easily finish the "story mode" in an hour at most
column20: but I think the execution of the fable was an experience that definite had me grinning as I played. It's decadent. It's cheeky. And as said before
column25: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This really is a wonderful game and presented very well.  From the music to the art and even the narrator, it feels like you are attending a Regency ball.  The theme also perfectly fits the game itself.  The pieces moving back and forth, trapping and countering, dodging and attacking... it all does look quite a bit like a dance even when their is blood spilt on the floor.  The story is short, but charming, and I would love to see more of it.  I quite enjoy the banter back and forth as the guests react as well, aghast at a fox somehow infiltrating their ballroom and eating them up.\n\nI, as others did, ran across a small bug during the story portion where the foxes would not move on their turn and got stuck.  I wrote the developers and received a reply within half an hour.  The next day it was fixed.  I can't say enough good about devs who are so responsive and quick to make sure their games are working properly.  It may be a small thing, but when Triple A developers let their games languish riddled with easily fixed bugs, it's nice to see people who actually have a passion for what they're doing and care for their product.  For under $2 this one is a real steal.

Hoping for more story's and dlc to this game as well as more games from the dev's in the future.

reviewText:
A lack of content overall, but what is there is good, and you can't complain about that with the low price.

There is an issue with pieces being obscured, though that does not make play impossible by any means.

I am confused by one mechanic, however.

The game explains that the flock can trap the foxes. However, in story mode, I managed to trap the flock as the foxes.

https://41.media.tumblr.com/04fb7c6f6397d7870dfd436854873da7/tumblr_nqbi48SIPK1r30qklo1_540.png

I'm not sure why the size is so small but you all should be able to figure it out.

Did the computer simply calculate that no future set of moves could achieve victory? If not, I have no idea how this works, because the computer could still make moves that would not entail losing a member of the flock.

reviewText:
A cute little game based on the old board game fox and geese. Other than that, there's not really a whole lot to say about the gameplay in general.

The story is passable, ( though, as a fan of foxes I wasn't too fond of the ending,) and will only take about an hour to play through. Great way to kill some time at a bus stop or an airport.

It has a quick start option, so after you beat the story there is still some playability, however I've discovered the AI can be duped into certain moves and as the foxes it can be quite easy to prevent the flock from winning by camping one of the nine spaces at the bottom (provided you are playing both foxes and not just one)

If you've played Fox and Geese (or if you haven't) this is a great little game to satisfy that itch (if you have one). If not, this game is a good little stepping off point to learn how.

reviewText: It's a very fun game, for a little while. The story to the game, though interesting, is insanely short. I finished it in less than an hour and after that just playing the 'quick game' function was pretty boring as it becamse very repetative after the first three times. If this was only a $1 or so, I would say go for it, but I don't think it's really $2 worth.

reviewText: Awesome game. It has a very clever way to present its jogability(which is super-fun btw), the drawings are good and the soundtrack is ♥♥♥♥ING AMAZING. For its price, this game is a must-be" for players that enjoy mental challenges! 8

Picked it up because the title reminded me of when my grandfather used to play Fox and Geese with me to teach me the basics of checkers and later chess. It's a simple game of strategy (that can also be deceptively tricky) with a short and charming story much like a fable. Took me less than an hour to play through and was just a nice relaxing play. If you're not a fan of chess or similar games though I wouldn't pick this up.

reviewText: This game is an odd combination of stylish visuals, cute presentation, lackluster content, and minor glitches that makes it hard to chose yes or no. I'm going with an overall thumbs down because I am not very enthusiastic about it in the end, but with the low price and its exactly what it says on the tin" presentation makes it worth buying if you're interested and want to give it a try anyway. You don't have a lot to lose if you want to try it.\n\nActually

recommended: nothing worse) I'd even give a thumbs up recommendation as a family game

reviewText:
Went into this game not really knowing how to play and finished the story mode in just under and hour with no losses. That being said, some levels were hard enough to provide a bit of a challenge and there is a quick game mode that will allow you  to play the game at a harder setting.

I enjoyed playing the story mode. The narration is superb, the dialogue clean and (at times) quite witty, the story was actually quite decent (with a twist even!) for a simple game, and the music was charming and relaxing. While the board and stylized characters can get a bit muddled when the flock clusters, there is a small representation of the board in the lower right hand corner to help sort things out.

The game is inexpensive, easy to learn, and a perfect time killer for those who like puzzles.
